Promoter.comment:
The Escherichia coli guaB promoter (PguaB) regulates transcription of the guaBA operon, encoding GuaB and GuaA, which are required for the de novo synthesis of GMP.

Between the guaB and guaA genes exists a 68-bp intercistronic region that contains a palindromic sequence and could form a possible ρ-independent terminator, but the effect of this possible hairpin loop should be modest over the expression of the guaB gene [Tiedeman85].

In 1977, Fukumaki et al. showed that the transcription of the guaA gene can be dependent on a secondary promoter located within the guaB gene, but the precise position was not located [Fukumaki77]. Evidence to demonstrate this was obtained by using a fago lambda-pguaA transducing phage [Fukumaki77].

The activity of guaBp is subject to growth rate-dependent control (GRDC), that is, the activity of guaBp increases as a function of the cellular growth rate [Davies96, Husnain08, Husnain08a]. Two elements are required for this regulation, an UP element, located between -59 and -38 relative to the guaB transcriptional start site [Husnain08], and a binding site for cAMP-CRP, located over 100 bp upstream of the transcription start site. cAMP-CRP, bound to this upstream site, downregulates guaBp. Downregulation is influenced by the growth rate and not by the carbon source [Husnain09]. The UP element, which is also required for GRDC, contains two independent subsites that are able to activate transcription independently. It stimulates guaBA transcription ~8- to 10-fold both in vivo and in vitro, and this activity requires the C-terminal domain of the RNA polymerase α-subunit [Husnain08]. The mechanism by which cAMP-CRP together with the UP element regulate transcription in a growth rate-dependent manner is not yet clear.

Based on deletion analysis, purified proteins of FIS, and multiple in vitro transcription assays, Husnain and Thomas (2008) [Husnain08a] proved that the putative FIS-binding sites (-126, -109, -92, and -76) located upstream of the guaBp core elements are not functional, since FIS does not bind in these sites, and they were removed from EcoCyc. Binding of FIS to sites FIS I, II, and III (-11, +8, and +29, respectively), identified by Husnain and Thomas (2008), represses transcription from guaBA ~8- to 10-fold in vitro but not in vivo [Husnain08a].

guaBp is repressed by PurR, and the binding site for PurR overlaps the core promoter [Husnain09, Davies96]. Expression of guaB is also repressed by DnaA in vivo. A consensus binding site, located approximately 200 bp downstream from the translation initiation codon, is required for DnaA-mediated repression at guaBp [TesfaSelase96, TesfaSelase92]. The role of a second, nonconsensus DnaA site overlapping the guaB promoter is not yet clear. In addition, guaBp carries a GC-rich discriminator [Andrews88].

Neither Fis nor DnaA or PurR is required for GRDC of guaBp [Husnain08a, Husnain09].
